title: 106_hr1556
content: The "Prevention of School Violence Act of 1999" emphasizes the importance of ensuring students' safety in schools. Despite schools being generally safe, recent violent incidents highlight the need for continued efforts to enhance school safety and create a conducive learning environment. There is a growing urgency to understand the root causes of student violence and implement effective prevention strategies. Establishment of National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence, known as the "National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence". Membership of the Commission. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence is composed of 11 members appointed by various officials. Appointing officials must consult with each other to ensure qualifications are met. Each appointee must meet specific qualifications. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints individuals with expertise in child and adolescent behavior, at-risk youth, school safety, and violence issues. The panel includes professionals with knowledge in violent and delinquent youth, juvenile justice, and media impact on children. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints professionals from various fields such as psychology, psychiatry, social work, school safety, and juvenile justice. They consult with experts from education, criminal justice, behavioral science, school safety, and psychology to address school violence and safety issues. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints professionals from various fields to address school violence and safety issues. The Commission includes individuals with experience in dealing with at-risk youth, public health officials, statisticians, criminologists, students, parents, and other experts in the field. The members elect a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with a majority constituting a quorum for business transactions. All appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints professionals from various fields to address school violence and safety issues. Members of the Commission may act on behalf of certain leaders in the House of Representatives and Senate. Each member has one equal vote, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers, and members receive no additional pay or benefits. Members of the National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence do not receive extra pay or benefits. Private citizens may get travel expenses for their service. The Commission's first meeting must take place within 40 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study school violence incidents, interviewing perpetrators, families, friends, teachers, and counselors for insights. Findings and recommendations will cover the extent and root causes of school violence, key factors, successful prevention approaches like early identification and conflict resolution. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 1 year, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for preventing school violence and ensuring a safe learning environment. Recommendations require a majority vote from Commission members. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission, upon request, can access federal agency facilities and services, as well as detail agency personnel to assist in their duties. They can use the United States mails and enter into contracts for research purposes. Staffing is subject to regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission has the power to appoint an Executive Director and additional staff without regard to certain provisions of the law, at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission's expenses are authorized to be appropriated up to $650,000 and remain available until expended or one year after the Commission's termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report.
